posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
A new era in robot vision

Hey y’all! You may have seen (somewhat) recent comments and threads about exploring the use of a Luxonis OAK-D stereo camera for VIO (Visual Inertial Odometry) in FRC , as a potential alternative here, with the help of @dragonblade316 .

To summarize what happened on that project, we couldn’t come to a licensing agreement with SpectacularAI (who made the Spectacular VIO algorithm) that would be suitable for a FRC environment. While we could have continued with that as an x86 only solution, we felt that ideally we would be able to use ARM based coprocessors as well, as they can be more efficient, more compact, and cheaper.

Since that project, Luxonis (the manufacturer of OAK-D cameras), has released an updated version of their API, known as DepthAI v3, which now includes several features that would be incredibly useful in a FRC context. These features include:

VIO/ VSLAM

Object tracking

2D AprilTag tracking

Given this feature set, we felt that the OAK-D remains a potential viable alternative to existing solutions in FRC , and is worth pursuing. Best of all, running this requires very minimal setup. All you need is a Linux host, clone the Python code, install the requirements in a virtual environment, and run it. That’s it, no more complicated setup.

An additional benefit to this is the size of the overall solution. For example, an OAK-D Lite measures only 91x28x17.5 mm. And ideally we imagine pairing it with a very small coprocessor, such as the Radxa Zero 3E . This results in a solution that is cheap, compact, and extremely quick and easy to get running. This solution should be able to be powered by a power bank or a USB-C power supply, such as the Redux Zinc-V, further simplifying the overall solution for teams. This particular combination of hardware should result in a very small, LimeLight-esque package, streamlining integration on the robot, with only a USB-C cable for power, and Ethernet for networking needing to be plugged into the overall package.

Right now, the project is hosted here: https://github.com/lasarobotics/PurpleRanger To play with it on your own machine if you have an OAK-D camera, run ./main.py --help to see the various options.

At the current time, VIO is an alpha feature in DepthAI v3, and we’ve noticed significant drift in the pose estimate. However, this is a bug, and we are working with the Luxonis developers to resolve this.

Here are some images, to provide a preview of what PurpleRanger is capable of now:

An example of VIO (exhibits the drift issue at the time of writing). The pose estimate is published over NetworkTables. The published table is very minimal.

An example of object tracking. The algorithm also provides coordinates of where the object is in space relative to the camera, using stereo vision to locate the object that was identified via the inference model. We believe this could prove very useful in tracking game objects, and driving towards them. This example is running yolov6-nano, on the camera’s built-in accelerator.

An example of the 2D AprilTag tracking pipeline. We hope to use this as an example to help us integrate AprilTag pose estimation into VIO.

For all three functions, a camera stream from the device is published at localhost:8080, as shown in the screenshots.

Regarding the future, we hope to have VIO working without drift soon, and work on integrating 3D AprilTag pose estimation into VIO, eliminating the need for external devices for pose initialization. We could potentially even run AprilTag pose estimation using both left and right stereo cameras, and merge those pose estimates, to provide more accurate AprilTag pose data to the overall algorithm.

Exploring the use of an Oak D lite and Spectacular AI for localization

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: If you’d like to help contribute to this project, feel free to reach out, and put in a pull request!

posts.name: Tauseef Afraz
posts.cooked: Will we see this working at TRI this weekend?

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
Unfortunately not, I figured its not worth gathering data with such significant drift in the VIO (which is the main use case for it).

We’ll be sure to conduct more testing at our shop, and publish the results here!

Hopefully it will be on the robot for DRIP!

posts.name: Roman A.
posts.cooked:
As someone whose been a champion of stereo technology adoption in FRC for a while now (5104 built a similar solution based on the ZED camera), this is awesome! Anything that can help bring stereo cameras to a wider audience here is a win in my books and I wish yall the best of luck!

I do however wonder to what degree the 480p stereo pair of the Lite specifically will impead localization accuracy compared to something like the S2.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.custom_user_title: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
That’s a good point, luckily there are many products in Luxonis’ range to try out. I am currently using the Pro W, and I was looking at the S2 as another cheaper option for “final product” as well, since QuestNav found that structured light (like the dot projector on the Pro W) didn’t help.

Also, you could just ignore tags that are estimated to be farther away, and only use them when they are very close and appear clearly even in a 480p image.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Another thing to note that in the future with SystemCore, it will likely be possible to not have a coprocessor for PurpleRanger at all, and just plug the OAK-D camera directly into the robot controller, and run this project on that alongside your robot code, making the system even smaller, and even easier to integrate.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
Basic AprilTag pose estimation is now functional, now have to work on integrating this into our VIO pipeline.

It does pose estimation on both left and right stereo camera images individually, and merges the poses with a simple interpolation.

Note in the following GIF, the device only has a single tag to look at (tag 10 in Reefscape)

posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked: What hardwere this project can run on?

posts.name: Teddy
posts.cooked:
We are targeting Luxonis RVC2 cameras. We are testing on the Oak D lite (my camera) and the Oak D pro W (Viggy’s camera) and it should work on the standard Oak D and other cameras in that lineup.

From there the software should work on most common SBCs (Orange pi, Raspberry pi, etc).

The software functions somewhat similar to photonvision in that it needs both a camera and an SBC.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: That one guy obsessed with programming

posts.custom_user_title: That one guy obsessed with programming

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
I believe I’ve resolved the VIO drift issue, and I’ve put in a pull request to Luxonis. Hopefully it gets merged in soon.

Here’s a 5 minute test of the device sitting motionless to see how much it drifts:

As you can see, it drifts very minimally over the course of 5 minutes. This is encouraging to see for future testing.

We’ll start work on merging AprilTag pose estimation, now that VIO doesn’t appear to drift anymore, and look into various sensor fusion techniques.

I’m also starting work on writing shell scripts and systemd service files to install PurpleRanger on various Linux distros easily, and automatically run it as a user level systemd service on boot. I hope to make using PurpleRanger as painless as possible.

Anyone who has ideas on sensor fusion strategies, feel free to chime in, we’d welcome the advice.

posts.name: Teddy
posts.cooked:
Quick update on this project. We have been continuing to work on this behind the scenes and have made some good progress.

We have decided for now to use RTABMap as our method for sensor fusion and SLAM. The main reason for this is convenience. Depthai (the library that powers our cameras) contains a wrapper for RTABMap that makes it rather easy for us to use.

RTABMap also supports various inputs allowing us to pass in both vio and apriltag detection and it will handle the fusion for us using its internal factor graph.

Unfortunately, Depthai does not at this moment have good support for using apriltags with rtabmap, so we have been working on adding the functionality.

The apriltag support is now compiling and not immediately crashing so hopefully we will be able to get this tested and merged into depthai-core soon.

Overall, things are looking good for this project at the moment, hopefully we can start accuracy and performance testing in the near future.

Edit: Did not mean for this to be a reply. Sorry for the ping.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: That one guy obsessed with programming

posts.custom_user_title: That one guy obsessed with programming

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
We have another exciting update!

After many long hours, we’ve managed to integrate AprilTags as markers into the RTABMap SLAM algorithm, which means that it will now use AprilTags along with VIO to provide a global pose estimate in WPILib’s field coordinate system all on its own, with no external initialization necessary.

Some fine tuning is still to come, as we experiment with the right values for various tunables. We also plan on various improvements in the future, such as providing the RTABMap algorithm a different covariance reading (similar to std dev) for every marker transform, using the IMU’s detected gravity vector to intelligently reject tags that appear to be in an incorrect orientation, and using stereo depth to help validate the solved AprilTag pose.

Note in the above test, only tag 10 is available to the camera.

Right now we’re working on fine tuning, and getting this running on various SBCs (Radxa Zero 3E, and Raspberry Pi 5).

If anyone would like to try this out, here’s a the depthai x86 Python wheel package you need to use, as it includes our changes: depthai-3.0.0rc3.dev0+98e2e7a89ad3927fdfd15d55249dde3c525dba7b-cp313-cp313-linux_x86_64.zip (39.8 MB)

EDIT: Please use the “slam-landmarks” branch of PurpleRanger, as that is where we are actively developing.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
Yet another update!

After doing some testing with RTABMap integrated into our pipeline to take advantage of its ability to use AprilTags as known  world markers, we found that the result was less than desirable. The pose estimate jumped often when moving around and going in and out of tag visibility. This pipeline remains in the code, in the hopes that it might become useful in the future, and our work adding the necessary functionality upstream into DepthAI v3 will be useful to many others.

Given the aforementioned observations, we decided to change our approach. We have implemented a particle filter, which uses the Basalt VIO algorithm and AprilTag pose estimates as inputs. Using this approach, the pose estimate output stream is much more stable, and accurate. I haven’t made measurements to quantify its accuracy, but it is a significant improvement from before.

In this test, I tried to move the camera in a very jerky way, to simulate the high accelerations of a robot moving and spinning around. As shown, it doesn’t appear to jump very much even when the camera is pointed back at the tag (again only tag 10 is available to the camera), which would seem to suggest that Basalt VIO is doing a pretty good job of keeping track of the device’s position even when tags are not available.

Further, the above test was executing on a Radxa Rock 5A as the SBC. It performs quite well, even with 2000 particles in the particle filter. Unfortunately this means that the Zero 3E that I originally wanted to use isn’t quite powerful enough to run this project in realtime. But, SBCs like the Rock 5A, and the Pi 5 are. This gives me great hope for PurpleRanger to run directly on SystemCore in future seasons, with no coprocessor necessary.

Finally, for those interested, here are some Python wheel packages for ARM and x86 to try out.

Tighten IMU covariance Depthai Python CI/CD #24

Tighten IMU covariance Depthai Python CI/CD #24

Depthai Python CI/CD #24

I am very hopeful to have this running on our robot at DRIP (our next off-season event), and gather more data.

P.S. It appears that Basalt, the VIO algorithm that we are using, is used in another open-source project, Monado XR , a cross-platform XR runtime. Here is a link to a talk done regarding VIO by a Monado developer.

posts.name: Jade
posts.cooked: Have you done any testing with this on a real robot?

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Not yet, I hope to do so very soon.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
I’ve also just added an install script for Debian/Ubuntu, which should get users up and running pretty quickly.

It sets up a systemd user service, and enables it to startup on boot automatically.

And it looks like Luxonis just merged in my drift fix for Basalt and put out a release including it, so there’s no need to manually install the wheel packages mentioned previously.
Do you have any updates on this project? Our team is pretty interested in using this as we have talked about using an Luxonis camera for a few years now.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Sorry for the delay. From testing at an off-season event, it seems like more computing power is needed to track effectively at higher frame rates, which would allow for better tracking at the high speeds typical in FRC . I recently got a Radxa NIO 12L, which has a more powerful ARM processor, which is closer to being on par with the chip in the Quest. I’m sure if you plan on using an x86 coprocessor, it would work better as well.
Another question, for the OAK-D PRO W that you are using, which option did you choose for the center camera?
